page.title: 12Richmond Park (1) Deer
page.content: Richmond Park is a Royal Park, six miles from the heart of London, completey surrounded by suburbia and is an oasis of rural England and natural history. The Park covers 2,300 acres, is walled by 9 miles of walls and has 6 gates open to traffic (5 of these date from Charles 1) and 4 foot gates. There are 7 miles of road within the Park. Two kinds of deer live in Richmond Park, the Red Deer and the Fallow Deer. They rut in October and the young are born the following Summer. Damage is done to the trees by the deer browsing the lower branches, especially of the sweet chestnut.The alder, ash, birch, oak, willow and beech are also present. The older oaks have been pollarded probably for firewood or for food for the deer in times of scarcity. (continued over)
